description.text: This project will establish productive farms and create access to commercial markets for women-headed households who have been re-settled in the districts of Lira, Apac and Oyam after the conflict in northern Uganda.  It will run for two years from August 2011.  It will directly support 1,800 poor women, each of whom looks after 5-8 children, many of them orphans, enabling them to improve the diet and food security for their families and generate incomes. An additional 3,000 families are expected to benefit from the market access, facilities and skills training provided.

title.text: Improved livelihood of women families in Northern Uganda through market led development

description.text:
To help national stakeholders working towards aid transparency in Nepal make use of appropriate tools and technologies for enhanced efficiency and

To build capacity of national stakeholders, specially NGOs in making use of
appropriate tools and technologies to better manage and present aid data
using IATI format
2. To maintain and update Nepal Aid website (www.nepalaid.net) with
relevant features, resources and content to to reflect on activities and
initiatives around Aid Transparency in Nepal.
3. Mobilize local technical community to develop appropriate visualization
tools to better present aid data
4. Initiate a small pilot open data initiative to make government spending
and foreign aid on a specific thematic area (eg. Water and sanitation)
available to general public in coordination with relevant stakeholders.
5. Disseminate information on how different tools and technologies can help
organizations achieve better aid transparency.

description.text:
Expected Outcome: Increased access to quality obstetric and neonatal health service in the districts, particularly among the most vulnerable groups (HIV positive, hard to reach and poorest pregnant women).
Related indicators are:
- Intrapartum and very early neonatal death rate at Emonc facilities
- Percentage of births assisted by a skilled attendant
- Percentage of HIV infected pregnant women who receive antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of MTCT
Expected Outputs:
- Iringa District Council Designated Hospital carries out quality and comprehensive emergency and obstetric and neonatal care with service available daily on a 24 hours basis
- Six health centers in Iringa District and two in Mufindi District are upgraded to offerbasic Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care
- Improved availability of quality health services for HIV positive mothers and exposed newborns at Iringa DC hospital and eight health centers into two districts
- A functional emergency referral system 24 hours a day, seven days a week is available within involved districts referring patients to Iringa DC Hospital
- Forty rural villages in Iringa District and twenty in Mufindi District are reache dby the network of Community Health Workers for community mobilization, awareness creation and behavioral change promotion
- Equity in access to emergency obstetric and newborn care in Iringa DC and Mufindi is improved to through reduction of barries to access
Direct Beneficiaries:
- Women in childberaring age (65640 in Iringa DC and 35992 in two divisions of Mufindi District) and particularly women with complicated deliveries (1300 in IDC and 700 in Mufindi)
- Newborns 8564 in IDC and 4760 in Mufindi District with special attentio to complicated deliveries
- Health staff trained  and re-trained (82)
- Community Health Workers  (102) and CHWs Supervisors (18)
- Number of women groups (20)
Indirect Beneficiaries:
- The total population  of Iringa DC and 2 divisions of Mufindi District (272707 and 128000 respectively). Subgropus: Households of involved villages (25000)
- Staff of the Hcs involved (180 in Iringa, 60 in Mufindi District)
- District Health Authorities: Council Health Management Team members (40), RHC members (10)

title.text: "Enabling access to improved mother and child health services for 101,632 women and newborn children in two districts of Tanzania”

description.text: The aidinfo programme works to reduce poverty by empowering citizens to make better use of money spent on poverty reduction.  By increasing access to information about resources for poverty reduction, it is hoped that ownership, accountability, effectiveness and efficiency of aid will be increased, improving the overall impact of aid and accelerating poverty reduction. Our work centres on research and advocacy on the value of transparency, support to the International Aid Transparency Initiative and supporting the users of aid information. This information relates to the first phase of the aidinfo programme.

description.text: Our aim is to ensure universal and lasting access to water and sanitation and hygiene as fundamental human rights. Unrestricted funding is essential to the way we work; It provides us with the flexibility to carry out work that is not covered by grants restricted to specific projects. This enables us to be more innovative,  and work on activities that are crucial  in  maximising our impact but may produce results that are hard to measure.  For example, it can help us to empower communities, support inclusion, and influence decision makers such as local and national government. It can be used to build the capacity of our staff and partner organisations, to monitor, research and learn from our work and share learning with others.  Finally, it provides our programmes with financial sustainability to ensure critical work can continue where there are funding gaps and unexpected costs.

description.text: The project will reduce sexual exploitation of children and young people in Rio de Janeiro. 40 girls and boys will access psychosocial support and information about their rights and sexual health. 400 children and youth will lead awareness campaigns on sexual exploitation, mobilising 2000 community members to understand, address and prevent it. 334 child-rights professionals, duty-bearers and authorities will be trained to tackle and prevent the problem.

title.text: Sexual Exploitation No! Mobilising young people and duty bearers in Rio de Janeiro

description.text: Our aim is to ensure universal and lasting access to water and sanitation and hygiene as fundamental human rights. Unrestricted funding is essential to the way we work; It provides us with the flexibility to carry out work that is not covered by grants restricted to specific projects. This enables us to be more innovative,  and work on activities that are crucial  in  maximising our impact but may produce results that are hard to measure.  For example, it can help us to empower communities, support inclusion, and influence decision makers such as local and national government. It can be used to build the capacity of our staff and partner organisations, to monitor, research and learn from our work and share learning with others.  Finally, it provides our programmes with financial sustainability to ensure critical work can continue where there are funding gaps and unexpected costs.
